Unit 1: Your First Day at Work - Session 2

Unit 1, Session 2 – Welcome to the Session

🧠 Unit 1, Session 2 – Welcome to the Session!

Welcome to Session 2 of Unit 1, where you’ll build essential English skills for workplace success, whether you’re in pre-primary education, industrial mechatronics, or social integration. This session dives into practical communication, helping you introduce yourself and navigate professional interactions with confidence.

This session will help you improve your English for real workplace situations. You’ll focus on how to introduce yourself, describe your personality, and understand how people communicate at work.

👂 In the Listening Activity, you’ll meet Anna, a new employee at Tip Top Trading, on her first day at work. You’ll hear how she introduces herself, meets her colleagues, and deals with a funny misunderstanding. This is a great opportunity to practise workplace communication and polite expressions in English.

🗣️ In the Vocabulary Section, you’ll explore useful phrases to talk about yourself professionally and describe your personality and work style. This will help you feel more confident when speaking in interviews, meetings, or work-based conversations.

🎯 By the end of this session, you’ll be able to:

  • Understand and use key phrases for introductions.
  • Describe your personal and professional qualities clearly.
  • Recognise cultural aspects of workplace communication.
  • Reflect on how to present yourself effectively in English.

💬 Tip: Imagine you’re starting a new job in your field. What would you say? What would you hear? Use this session to prepare!

💭 Reflect

Picture yourself in Anna’s shoes on your first day in a new workplace. What phrases would you use to introduce yourself? How might understanding workplace culture (like Anna’s “do lunch” mix-up) help you communicate better in your vocational field?

Practise a few phrases from this session out loud to feel ready for real-world conversations!

✨ Let’s dive in — and get ready to shine in your professional journey!

Listening Activity: English at Work Episode 1

🧠 Unit 1, Session 2 – Listening Introduction

Welcome to the listening activity for Session 2 of Unit 1! In this activity, you’ll dive into “English at Work: Episode 1,” where Anna starts her first day as a Sales Executive at Tip Top Trading. Listen to her introduce herself to colleagues like Tom, navigate office interactions, and resolve a funny misunderstanding about “doing lunch.” This exercise will help you understand workplace communication, polite introductions, and key phrases, preparing you for your speaking and writing tasks.

🎧 About the Activity
The listening task focuses on understanding the episode’s plot, characters, and key expressions, such as Anna’s introduction phrases. You’ll also explore the cultural nuance of “Can you do lunch?” to avoid misunderstandings like Anna’s. The comprehension questions that follow will test your grasp of these elements.

Strategies for Listening Success:

  • Predict Content: Before listening, think about Anna’s first day—expect topics like introductions, workplace roles, or misunderstandings.
  • Listen for Key Phrases: Focus on phrases like “Hello, I don’t think we’ve met” or “Nice to meet you” to catch polite introductions.
  • Identify Context Cues: Note speakers’ roles (e.g., Tom as Senior Account Manager) and situations (e.g., the lunch mix-up) to understand the dialogue.
  • Take Notes: During your second listen, jot down main ideas or unfamiliar words to help answer comprehension questions.

💭 Reflect

Imagine you’re starting a new job in your vocational field (e.g., Social Integration, Pre-Primary Education). What phrases might you hear or use to introduce yourself? How could listening to Anna’s experience help you prepare?

Use these strategies to listen actively — they’ll boost your confidence and comprehension!

✨ Get ready to master workplace English with Anna’s first day!

🎬 English at Work Episode 1 Comprehension Practice

🎯 Introduction

Test your understanding of the video "English at Work: Episode 1," where Anna starts her new job at Tip Top Trading. These activities focus on the plot, characters, polite introductions, and the misunderstanding about "doing lunch." Watch the video below, then complete the 20 items across four exercises. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

Scoring: Each correct answer is worth 1 point (20 points total). Aim for 16/20 (≥80%) to confirm understanding. If you score less than 16, rewatch the video or review the transcript.

💡 Tip: Listen for key phrases and visualize Anna’s interactions in the office!

❓ Exercise 1: Multiple Choice Questions (5 items)

Instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question about the video. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. What is Anna’s new job at Tip Top Trading?

  • 2. How does Anna feel on her first day?

  • 3. Who is Tom Darcy?

  • 4. What does Tom mean by “Can you do lunch?”

  • 5. How does the situation resolve at the end?

💡 Tip: Think about the main events and characters’ roles in the video.

✅ Exercise 2: True or False Statements (5 items)

Instructions: Decide if each statement is true or false based on the video. Check the box for true statements. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 6. Anna introduces herself politely to Tom.

  • 7. Tom is very welcoming and chats with Anna.

  • 8. Anna understands Tom’s lunch invitation correctly.

  • 9. Denise helps Anna cook lunch in the kitchen.

  • 10. Paul suggests having an office picnic.

💡 Tip: Pay attention to specific details, especially the lunch misunderstanding.

📝 Exercise 3: Fill in the Blanks – Introduction Phrases (5 items)

Instructions: Complete Anna’s introduction phrases with the correct word or phrase. Type the exact word(s). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 11. Hello, I don’t think we’ve ___.

  • 12. You ___ be Tom.

  • 13. I’ve ___ joined the team.

  • 14. ___ to meet you.

  • 15. Have you ___ here long?

💡 Tip: Recall how Anna introduces herself to Tom at the start.

🔗 Exercise 4: Matching – Dialogue to Speaker (5 items)

Instructions: Match each dialogue line to the correct speaker from the video. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 16. “Can you do lunch tomorrow?”

  • 17. “Spring rolls, followed by crispy duck in black bean sauce.”

  • 18. “Anna thinks it’s her job to cook for people!”

  • 19. “I think that’s a splendid idea, we can have an office picnic!”

  • 20. “I’ve just joined the team.”

💡 Tip: Think about who says what during key moments, like the lunch mix-up.

📊 Your Score

Click "Check Answers" in each section to see your score.

Unit 1, Session 2 – Vocabulary Focus and Practice

🧠 Unit 1, Session 2 – Vocabulary Focus and Practice

Building on Session 2’s focus on describing yourself, like Anna’s introductions in the listening activity, this vocabulary section equips you with tools to shine in workplace communication. Whether you’re in social integration, pre-primary education, or logistics, these terms will boost your confidence in professional settings.

Welcome to the vocabulary section of Session 2! In this session, you’ll learn and practise useful phrases and adjectives to introduce yourself and describe your personality, both in personal and professional contexts. These expressions will help you communicate more confidently during interviews, at work, and in networking situations.

You’ll explore:

  • 🗣️ Phrases to talk about your background, job and interests.
  • 💼 Adjectives to describe your personality and working style.
  • 🌟 Vocabulary to present your professional profile clearly and effectively.

This vocabulary will support you in speaking and writing tasks, and help you make a great impression in your vocational field. Use the examples to personalise your language, and reflect on which words best describe who you are and how you work. Let’s get started!

💭 Reflect

Think about a professional situation in your vocational field (e.g., meeting a new colleague or attending an interview). Which aspects of your background, personality, or skills would you highlight? How could new vocabulary help you express this?

Choose a few phrases or adjectives that feel like “you” to make your introductions authentic and impactful!

✨ Dive into the vocabulary and start crafting your professional identity!

Unit 1, Session 2 – Vocabulary: Introducing Yourself and Describing Your Personality

🧠 Unit 1, Session 2 – Vocabulary Overview

Welcome to the vocabulary section for Session 2 of Unit 1! This section equips you with essential phrases and adjectives to introduce yourself and describe your personality in professional and personal contexts. Whether you’re meeting colleagues like Anna in the listening activity or preparing a job interview, these terms will help you communicate confidently. Use this vocabulary to excel in your speaking and writing tasks and shine in your vocational field!
🎧 Complementary Audio – Guided Explanation
This audio supports you as you go through the lesson. Listen to it for a step-by-step explanation with spoken examples. It’s especially helpful if you prefer learning by listening or want to review while doing other tasks.

🗣️ Section 2.1 – Introducing Yourself

Introducing yourself confidently is key to making a great first impression in any workplace, from a social services centre to a logistics company. This section provides practical phrases to share your background, role, and interests clearly and naturally.

By the end of this section, you’ll be able to:

  • Introduce yourself professionally and naturally.
  • Clearly explain your educational background, current role, and previous experiences.
  • Highlight your strengths and unique personal qualities effectively.

Phrases for Self-Introduction:

  • 👤 Name and Greeting
    • Hi, I’m [Name]. Example: Hi, I’m Laura.
    • My name is [Name]. Example: My name is Carlos.
    • Hello, my name is [Name]. Example: Hello, my name is Sofia.
  • 💼 Occupation
    • I work as a [Job]. Example: I work as a social integration technician.
    • I’m a [Job]. Example: I’m a maintenance technician.
    • I’m employed in [Field]. Example: I’m employed in early childhood education.
  • 🌍 Background
    • I’m from [Place]. Example: I’m from Seville.
    • I currently live in [Place]. Example: I currently live in Madrid.
    • I studied [Field] at [Institution]. Example: I studied Industrial Maintenance at a vocational school.
  • 🎯 Interests
    • I enjoy [Activity]. Example: I enjoy cycling.
    • I’m passionate about [Interest]. Example: I’m passionate about helping others.
    • My hobbies include [Activity]. Example: My hobbies include DIY projects.
  • 🗣️ Languages and Experience
    • I speak [Language]. Example: I speak English and Spanish.
    • I have [Number] years of experience in [Field]. Example: I have three years of experience in logistics.
    • I’ve worked at [Company]. Example: I’ve worked at a community centre.
  • 🔮 Goals
    • I’m looking forward to [Goal]. Example: I’m looking forward to specializing in automation.
    • My goal is to [Aspiration]. Example: My goal is to work internationally.
  • 🤝 Pleasantries
    • Nice to meet you! Example: Nice to meet you, Tom!
    • It’s a pleasure to meet you. Example: It’s a pleasure to meet you, Ms. Lopez.
    • How about you? Example: I’m a technician. How about you?

💭 Reflect: Which phrases would you use to introduce yourself in your vocational field? How could you combine them? (e.g., “Hi, I’m Ana. I’m a social worker, and I’m passionate about inclusion.”)

Practise these phrases out loud to sound natural and confident in your introductions!

💼 Section 2.2 – Adjectives to Describe Your Personality

Your personality shapes how you connect with colleagues and clients. This section offers adjectives to describe your personal traits, helping you present yourself authentically in professional and informal settings, like Anna’s introductions in the listening activity.

By the end of this section, you’ll be able to:

  • Describe your personality with precise adjectives.
  • Use personality traits to enhance your self-introduction.
  • Choose adjectives that reflect your unique qualities.

Personality Adjectives:

  • 😊 Positive Traits
    • Cheerful: Always happy and positive. Example: I’m cheerful, so I bring energy to my team.
    • Confident: Sure of your abilities. Example: I’m confident when presenting my ideas.
    • Optimistic: Seeing the bright side. Example: I’m optimistic, which helps me solve challenges.
  • 🤗 Emotional Traits
    • Kind: Caring and considerate. Example: I’m kind, so I support my colleagues.
    • Empathetic: Understanding others’ feelings. Example: I’m empathetic, which helps me connect with clients.
    • Patient: Calm under pressure. Example: I’m patient when teaching new skills.
  • 💪 Work-Related Traits
    • Hardworking: Dedicated to tasks. Example: I’m hardworking, so I always meet deadlines.
    • Reliable: Dependable and trustworthy. Example: I’m reliable, so my team counts on me.
    • Creative: Full of new ideas. Example: I’m creative in designing activities.
  • 🌐 Social Traits
    • Friendly: Easy to talk to. Example: I’m friendly, so I build good relationships.
    • Outgoing: Sociable and open. Example: I’m outgoing, which helps me network.
    • Supportive: Helping others succeed. Example: I’m supportive, always assisting my team.

💭 Reflect: Which personality adjective best describes you? How would you use it in a sentence? (e.g., “I’m empathetic, so I understand my clients’ needs.”)

Choose one or two personality adjectives to include in your next introduction for a personal touch!

💼 Section 2.3 – Useful Adjectives for Professional Contexts

When you introduce yourself or describe your strengths in English, adjectives play a key role. They help you express who you are, how you work, and what makes you a great professional. Whether you are applying for a job, writing a short profile, or preparing for a speaking task, using precise adjectives will make your communication clearer, stronger, and more personal.

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Explore a list of useful adjectives related to your professional profile.
  • Organise vocabulary by areas such as technical skills, communication, or attitude.
  • Choose the words that best describe you for your writing and speaking tasks.

🌟 Useful Adjectives for Vocational Contexts

  • 🔧 Technical and Organisational Skills
    • Detail-oriented: Focused on accuracy and small elements in a task or project. Example: I’m detail-oriented, so I ensure reports are error-free.
    • Precise: Able to work with accuracy and attention to exact information. Example: I’m precise in measuring materials.
    • Methodical: Working step by step, in a systematic and organised way. Example: I’m methodical when planning projects.
    • Systematic: Using a clear and logical method in completing tasks. Example: I’m systematic in organizing schedules.
    • Efficient: Getting tasks done in a short time with good results. Example: I’m efficient, finishing tasks quickly.
    • Resourceful: Good at solving problems and finding solutions with what is available. Example: I’m resourceful, finding tools to fix issues.
    • Analytical: Able to examine information carefully to understand or solve problems. Example: I’m analytical, so I solve technical problems.
    • Organised: Good at planning and keeping things in order. Example: I’m organised, keeping my workspace tidy.
    • Reliable: Someone you can trust to do things well and on time. Example: I’m reliable, always meeting deadlines.
    • Skilled: Having the training or ability to do something well. Example: I’m skilled in using software tools.
  • 🤝 Social and Communication Skills
    • Friendly: Kind, pleasant and easy to talk to. Example: I’m friendly, making clients feel welcome.
    • Approachable: Easy for others to talk to or ask for help. Example: I’m approachable, so colleagues ask me for advice.
    • Empathetic: Able to understand and share other people’s feelings. Example: I’m empathetic, supporting team members.
    • Patient: Calm and tolerant, even in difficult situations. Example: I’m patient when training new staff.
    • Respectful: Showing consideration and politeness to others. Example: I’m respectful, valuing others’ opinions.
    • Supportive: Helping and encouraging others when they need it. Example: I’m supportive, helping my team succeed.
    • Collaborative: Good at working together with others as a team. Example: I’m collaborative, working well in groups.
    • Clear: Easy to understand when speaking or writing. Example: I’m clear when explaining tasks.
    • Polite: Showing good manners in words and actions. Example: I’m polite, always using kind words.
    • Good listener: Paying full attention when someone speaks. Example: I’m a good listener, understanding clients’ needs.
  • 🚀 Attitude and Professional Behaviour
    • Responsible: Taking care of duties and accepting the results of actions. Example: I’m responsible, ensuring tasks are complete.
    • Proactive: Taking initiative and acting before being asked. Example: I’m proactive, suggesting new ideas.
    • Flexible: Able to adapt to different tasks or situations easily. Example: I’m flexible, handling unexpected changes.
    • Committed: Dedicated and loyal to a task or team. Example: I’m committed to my team’s goals.
    • Creative: Thinking of new ideas or original ways to do things. Example: I’m creative in solving problems.
    • Motivated: Having a strong reason and energy to do something well. Example: I’m motivated to improve my skills.
    • Adaptable: Comfortable with change and new challenges. Example: I’m adaptable, thriving in new roles.
    • Focused: Concentrating and not being distracted. Example: I’m focused during complex tasks.
    • Honest: Telling the truth and acting with integrity. Example: I’m honest, always being truthful.
    • Independent: Able to work and make decisions without needing help. Example: I’m independent, managing my tasks alone.
  • 🎓 Learning and Development
    • Curious: Eager to learn and discover new things. Example: I’m curious, always exploring new methods.
    • Open-minded: Willing to consider new ideas and perspectives. Example: I’m open-minded, accepting feedback.
    • Observant: Quick to notice things and pay attention to detail. Example: I’m observant, spotting errors quickly.
    • Quick learner: Able to understand and apply new things fast. Example: I’m a quick learner, mastering new tools.
    • Willing to improve: Open to feedback and interested in getting better. Example: I’m willing to improve my skills daily.
    • Reflective: Thinking carefully about actions and experiences to learn from them. Example: I’m reflective, learning from mistakes.
    • Self-motivated: Driven to complete tasks without needing pressure or reminders. Example: I’m self-motivated, setting my own goals.
    • Resilient: Strong in difficult situations and able to recover from setbacks. Example: I’m resilient, bouncing back from challenges.
    • Innovative: Using creativity to find new and effective solutions. Example: I’m innovative, creating new processes.
    • Growth-oriented: Focused on learning and personal development over time. Example: I’m growth-oriented, seeking new skills.

💭 Reflect: Which professional adjective describes your work style? How would you use it? (e.g., “I’m reliable, so I always complete tasks on time.”)

Pick a few adjectives to describe your strengths in your next speaking or writing task for a professional edge!

📋 Summary Table

Section Example Term/Phrase Purpose Sample Use
2.1 Introducing Yourself I work as a [Job] State your occupation I work as a social integration technician.
2.1 Introducing Yourself Nice to meet you! Express politeness Nice to meet you, Maria!
2.2 Personality Adjectives Empathetic Describe emotional traits I’m empathetic, understanding clients’ needs.
2.2 Personality Adjectives Hardworking Describe work ethic I’m hardworking, meeting all deadlines.
2.3 Professional Adjectives Detail-oriented Highlight technical skills I’m detail-oriented, ensuring accurate reports.
2.3 Professional Adjectives Collaborative Emphasize teamwork I’m collaborative, working well in teams.

✨ Master these terms to introduce yourself with confidence and professionalism!

🗣️ Introducing Yourself and Describing Your Personality Practice

🎯 Introduction

Master the vocabulary from Unit 1, Session 2 to introduce yourself and describe your personality confidently! These activities help you practice phrases for introductions, personality adjectives, and professional adjectives in professional and personal contexts, like meeting colleagues or preparing for a job interview. Complete the 24 items across four exercises. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

Scoring: Each correct answer is worth 1 point (24 points total). Aim for 19/24 (≈80%) to confirm readiness. If you score less than 19, review the vocabulary section.

💡 Tip: Visualize meeting a new colleague or interviewing for a job as you answer!

📋 Exercise 1: Gap-Fill – Self-Introduction Phrases (6 items)

Instructions: Fill in the blanks with the correct self-introduction phrase. Type the exact phrase (e.g., “My name is”). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. ___ Laura. Nice to meet you!

  • 2. I ___ as a logistics coordinator.

  • 3. I’m ___ Seville.

  • 4. I ___ about helping others.

  • 5. I ___ English and Spanish.

  • 6. I’m looking ___ to working in social services.

💡 Tip: Imagine introducing yourself at a new job—what phrases fit?

🔗 Exercise 2: Matching – Personality Adjectives to Definitions (6 items)

Instructions: Match each personality adjective to its correct definition by selecting from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 7. Cheerful

  • 8. Empathetic

  • 9. Hardworking

  • 10. Outgoing

  • 11. Kind

  • 12. Optimistic

💡 Tip: Think about how these adjectives describe someone’s personality!

❓ Exercise 3: Multiple Choice – Professional Adjectives in Context (6 items)

Instructions: Choose the professional adjective that best fits each workplace scenario. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 13. I ensure reports are error-free. I’m ___.

  • 14. I suggest new ideas before being asked. I’m ___.

  • 15. I work well in teams. I’m ___.

  • 16. I master new tools fast. I’m a ___.

  • 17. I’m calm when training new staff. I’m ___.

  • 18. I plan projects step by step. I’m ___.

💡 Tip: Match the adjective to the workplace behavior described!

📝 Exercise 4: Sentence Completion – Combine Phrases and Adjectives (6 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence using an introduction phrase and a personality or professional adjective, explaining why. Type the exact phrase and adjective (e.g., “My name is empathetic”). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 19. ___, and I’m ___ because I support my colleagues.

  • 20. ___, and I’m ___ because I ensure accuracy in reports.

  • 21. ___, and I’m ___ because I bring energy to my team.

  • 22. ___, and I’m ___ because I work well with others.

  • 23. ___, and I’m ___ because I learn new skills quickly.

  • 24. ___, and I’m ___ because I see the bright side.

💡 Tip: Use an introduction phrase and an adjective that fits the reason given!

📊 Your Score

Click "Check Answers" in each section to see your score.
